intro: Galium circaezans var. lanceolatum, commonly known as the lanceleaf bedstraw, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to parts of North America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and opposite, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces small, white to pale pink flowers that bloom in clusters during the summer months. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its hairy stems and leaves give it a distinctive appearance, and it is often found in moist, well-drained soils.
